candidate_text: The n-dimensional rotation matrix formula!

For an n-dimensional space, to rotate a vector by an angle Œ∏ around an arbitrary axis defined by a unit vector (a‚ÇÅ, a‚ÇÇ,..., an), the rotation matrix can be constructed as follows:

1.
In general, an n-dimensional rotation matrix can be represented as an orthogonal matrix of size n x n, that preserves the Euclidean norm of vectors.

For an n-dimensional space, to rotate a vector by an angle Œ∏ around an arbitrary axis, to use the Rodrigues' rotation formula, which is given as:

R = I + sin(Œ∏) * K + (1 - cos(Œ∏)) * K^2

Where R is the rotation matrix, I is the identity matrix, and K is the skew-symmetric matrix corresponding to the cross product with the unit vector along the rotation axis.
In general, it's quite challenging to provide a single, formula that covers all cases of n-dimensional rotations.

For an n-dimensional space, to rotate a vector by an angle Œ∏ around a unit vector (a1, a2,..., an), the rotation matrix R can be expressed as:

R = I + sin(Œ∏) \* K + (1 - cos(Œ∏)) \* K^2

where:

* I is the identity matrix (an nxn matrix with 1's on the main diagonal and 0's elsewhere)
* K is the skew-symmetric matrix defined as:

K_ij = a_i * aj - ai * aj (i ‚â† j; i, j = 1, 2,..., n)

The values of a_i are the components of the unit vector (a1, a2,..., an).
This formula works for any dimension n ‚â• 3.
This formula generates an orthogonal matrix R that rotates a vector in the n-dimensional space.
This formula is often referred to as Rodrigues' rotation formula.
Note that this formula represents a rotation in the plane spanned by the vectors v and (ai, ai,..., an).
This is a generalization of the well-known Rodrigues' rotation formula for 3D spaces.

To simplify this formula, we can rewrite it in terms of the cross-product operator ‚äó:

R = exp(Œ∏ * (a ‚äó))

This is known as Rodrigues' rotation formula.

To break it down further:

* When i = j, K_ij = 0 (since a_i * ai - ai * ai = 0)
* When i ‚â† j, K_ij = -K_ji (due to the skew-symmetry property)

This rotation matrix formula works for any dimension n ‚â• 2.

Please note that when n = 3 (in 3D space), this reduces to the familiar Euler-Rodrigues formula:

R = I + sin(Œ∏) \* [ax] + (1 - cos(Œ∏)) \* [ax]^2

Where [ax] is the skew-symmetric cross-product matrix associated with the unit vector ax.
Keep in mind that this is just one way to represent rotations in higher dimensions, and there are other approaches, like using quaternions or Lie algebras.
